column3: OpenSearch index slow logging should be enabled
column4: OpenSearch (ElasticSearch) domain index slow logs should be enabled
column5:
That will help you identify performance issues caused by specific queries or changes in cluster usage.
It is recommended to enable index slow logs to optimize your index configuration in order to address future problems.

column3: OpenSearch node to node encryption should be enabled
column4: OpenSearch (ElasticSearch) domain should be set to encrypt node to node
column5: It is recommended to enable node-to-node encryption to ensure that the data that is sent to the OpenSearch domain over HTTPS remains encrypted in-flight while it is being distributed and redistributed through the clusters.

column3: OpenSearch policy should not allow unrestricted access for all users
column4: OpenSearch (ElasticSearch) domain policy should not be overly permissive
column5: It is recommended to follow the principle of least privilege (PoLP) and update the resource policy to exclude the permissive statement(s) from the access policy to protect the resource from data leakage and unauthorized access.

column3: OpenSearch search slow logging should be enabled
column4: OpenSearch (ElasticSearch) domain search slow logs should be enabled
column5:
Enabling search slow logs allows you to publish slow logs from the indexing and search operations performed on your OpenSearch clusters to AWS CloudWatch and gain full insight into the performance of these operations.
This will help you identify performance issues caused by specific queries or changes in cluster usage.
It is recommended to enable search slow logs to optimize your search configuration in order to address future problems.

column3: OpenSearch service domain should restrict public access
column4: OpenSearch (ElasticSearch) domain should not be publicly accessible
column5:
Placing an OpenSearch domain within a VPC enables secure communication between OpenSearch Service and other services within the VPC without the need for an internet gateway, NAT device, or VPN connection.
It is recommended to use a VPC access instead of a public one to secure all traffic within the AWS cloud.

column3: OpenSearch zone awareness should be enabled
column4: OpenSearch (ElasticSearch) domain zone awareness should be enabled
column5:
This rule checks whether the OpenSearch Service (formerly Amazon Elasticsearch Service) Domain has Zone Awareness enabled.
This rule fails if the ZoneAwarenessConfig does not exist or ZoneAwarenessEnabled is false.
Distributing data nodes across two or three availability zones in the same AWS region helps to prevent data loss and minimize OpenSearch cluster downtime in the event of a service disruption.

column3: Classic Load Balancer should have connection draining enabled
column4: Classic Load Balancer should have connection draining enabled
column5: This rule checks whether the load balancer is configured with connection draining, which ensures that the load balancer stops sending requests to unhealthy instances, while keeping the existing connections open. When disabled, connections to unhealthy instances are immediately closed and some requests may not be completed.

column3: Classic Load Balancer should have cross-zone load balancing enabled
column4: Classic Load Balancer cross-zone load balancing should be enabled
column5: This rule checks whether cross-zone load balancing is enabled on the load balancer. When enabled, traffic is distributed to instances registered in all enabled Availability Zones, providing better fault tolerance and more consistent traffic flow. When disabled, the load balancer distributes traffic to targets within its Availability Zone only.

column4: ELBv2 should have deletion protection enabled
column5: This rule checks whether the deletion_protection attribute is enabled. When disabled, the load balancer is prone to irreversible data loss due to accidental operations. ELBv2 should have deletion protection enabled to ensure that it cannot be accidentally deleted.

column3: Elastic Load Balancer should have one or more listeners configured
column4: Elastic Load Balancer should use SSL listeners
column5: This rule checks whether the load balancer is configured with a listener that uses encryption, either a TLS or an HTTPS listener. A load balancer not serving encrypted traffic increases the security risk of clients connecting to the load balancer. At least one listener with an encryption-supported protocol should be configured.

column3: Elastic Load Balancer should not have invalid HTTP headers
column4: Application Load Balancer should drop invalid headers
column5: This rule checks if the Application Load Balancer has the Drop Invalid Header Fields feature enabled.

column3: ELBv2 application load balancer exposed to internet traffic should be attached to WAF
column4: Application Load Balancer should be integrated with a WAF
column5:
This rule checks if the Application Load Balancer (ALB) is integrated and protected by a Web Application Firewall (WAF).
You can use AWS WAF with your ALB to allow or block requests based on the rules in a web access control list (web ACL).
It is recommended to protect your web applications by enabling AWS WAF directly on your load balancer.

column3: Elastic Load Balancer should not use a default VPC
column4: Default VPC should not exist

column3: SQS queue policy should restrict access to required users
column4: SQS Queue policy should not allow access to all principals
column5: limit access to only those who require it, and disable public access unless required for business needs.

column3: SQS queue should be encrypted with a customer master key
column4: SQS Queue should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
column5: Use a customer-managed CMK to encrypt SQS queues so that only users in the account with access to the CMK can view or manage the data.

column3: SQS queue should have encryption enabled
column4: SQS Queue should enforce server-side encryption
column5: Configure at-rest encryption through AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for SQS queues.

column3: RDS DB instance should not have Multi-AZ support disabled
column4: Database instance multi-availability zone should be enabled

column3: RDS DB cluster should not have deletion protection disabled
column4: Database cluster deletion protection should be enabled
column5: Enabling cluster deletion protection is an additional layer of protection against accidental database deletion or deletion by an unauthorized entity.

column3: RDS DB instance backup retention period should be greater than 30 days
column4: Database instance backup retention period should be at least a week (RDS-001)
column5: RDS DB instance backup retention period should be greater than 30 days

column3: RDS DB instance should have automatic minor version upgrades enabled
column4: Database instance automatic minor version upgrade should be enabled
column5: Enable automatic upgrades to RDS minor versions to ensure that security updates are applied as quickly as possible.

column3: RDS DB instance should restrict public access
column4: Not present in WIZ
column5: When an RDS instance is publicly accessible and configured appropriately, any internet host can connect directly to the database. For a more secure option, provision RDS instances only within a VPC, disable public access whenever possible, and use security groups to control access

column3: RDS DB snapshot should have encryption enabled
column4: Database cluster encryption should be enabled
column5: Encryption provides an additional layer of security to your data in the event of loss, breach, theft or other kinds of compromise. Enable RDS encryption for automatic encryption of instance and snapshot data at rest.

column3: CloudTrail log file should be integrated with CloudWatch
column4: CloudTrail event should be integrated with CloudWatch

column3: Lambda function environment variables should be encrypted with a customer master key
column4: Lambda function environment variables should be encrypted at rest with KMS customer master key
column5: Ensure your AWS Lambda function environment variables are encrypted with a customer managed CMK stored in AWS Key Management Service (KMS)

column3: Redshift cluster encryption should be enabled
column4: Redshift cluster should be encrypted
column5: Enable encryption on Redshift clusters to protect against data breaches.

column3: Redshift cluster should have audit logging enabled
column4: Redshift cluster user activity logs should be enabled
column5: Enable this feature to to maintain a history of your user activity logs for evidence during security audits and other investigations.

column3: Redshift cluster should have user activity logging enabled
column4: Redshift cluster connection logs should be enabled
column5: Amazon Redshift can track user activity and log connection data, user configuration changes, and other user requests. Enable this feature to provide an audit trail for any unknown or suspicious actions.

column3: Redshift cluster should require SSL connections
column4: Redshift cluster SSL mode should be enabled
column5: Require SSL connections for Redshift to protect data in transit.

column3: Systems Manager managed instance association should be in compliant status
column4: Not present in WIZ
column5: Ensure Systems Manager managed instance association compliance status is compliant

column3: Systems Manager managed instance patch should be in compliant status
column4: Not present in WIZ
column5: Ensure Systems Manager managed instance patch compliance status is compliant

column3: KMS service should be enabled
column4: Not present in WIZ
column5: Enable KMS to generate cryptographic keys and use them to encrypt data in AWS.

column3: KMS should have automated key rotation enabled
Kinesis data stream should be encrypted
column4: Kinesis should enforce server-side encryption
column5: Ensure Amazon Kinesis data stream server side encryption is enabled.

column3: GuardDuty is not configured for all the enabled regions
column4: GuardDuty Detector should be enabled
column5: Ensure GuardDuty is configured for all the enabled regions.

column3: An IAM user has a managed policy directly attached to the user
column4: IAM User should not have any policies attached
column5: It is recommended that IAM policies are applied directly to groups or roles, but not to users.

column3: IAM account should not be inactive for 90 days or longer
column4: IAM User should not be inactive for more than 90 days
column5: It is recommended that all users who have been inactive for 90 or more days be disabled or removed.

column3: IAM active server certificate should be renewed before it expires
column4: ACM certificate expiring within 30 days should be renewed
column5: There are one or more active server certificate that will expire in the next 30 days. Expired certificates can break applications and reduce customer trust. Furthermore, manually accepting expired certificates as valid can mask other security risks which can lead to phishing, Man In The Middle attack, and other identity spoofing attacks.

column3: IAM groups should have one or more users defined
column4: Not present in WIZ
column5: delete any empty IAM groups.

column3: IAM policy should not have unlimited administrative privileges
column4: IAM policy should not have full administrative access
column5: should limit IAM policies to the minimum necessary permissions

column3: IAM user credentials should be removed if inactive for 30 days of more
column4: 1>   IAM User credentials unused for 45 days or more should be disabled                                                                    2>  Access keys unused for 30 days or more should be    disabled
column5: If one or more access key sets are older than 30 days, the keys are most likely associated with a compromised or abandoned IAM user account; therefore, it is recommended that these credentials are disabled or removed.

column3: IAM user, group, or role should generally not have access to update Lambda function versions
column4: Not present in WIZ
column5: Update IAM policy statement attached to the IAM user, group, or role by removing permissions to update Lambda functions' code.

column3: IAM user, group, or role should have MFA permissions restricted
column4: IAM assumed role cross account should have an external ID or MFA (IAM-057) and IAM User with console access should have MFA enabled (IAM-005)
column5: There is a user, group, or role with permissions to deactivate and reset multi-factor authentication (MFA) for other IAM user, groups, or role. While MFA is a strong security control for protecting privileged IAM permissions in AWS, it can be compromised if left unrestricted. A malicious individual could deactivate and reset a users MFA device and remove the protection built around sensitive and privileged IAM permissions.
